page.title: 02Landscape
page.content: The open landscape has been described as "arable desert".Although a line of ancient oak and ash woods (including Hanger, Astey, Kempston and Ransom's woods) do remain,trees have been lost in the area through enlargement of fields and removal of hedgerows and roadside trees.Elm was the most common hedgerow tree but has been lost through disease.The oak and ash remaining suffer "die-back" due to farming pracices of cultivating too near the roots,drainage, chemicals and straw burning. Remaining trees are important and many trees around Stagsden West End have Tree Preservation Orders.Some replanting has occured;the County Council and private landowners have planted some trees e.g.at Ducksworth (to replace those lost due to road improvements)and Stagsden West End.
